Instrument.name: Ultraviolet Spectrometer for Galileo Orbiter
Instrument.description: The Galileo Orbiter Ultraviolet Spectrometer (UVS) gathered data to improve knowledge of the interstellar wind and of the processes that affect its passage through the solar system. The UVS instrument consists of a Cassegrain telescope, with effective focal length 250 mm and focal ratio of f/5, and an 125 mm focal length Ebert-Fastie scanning spectrometer. The field of view of the telescope is wavelength-dependent, being limited by the spectrometer entrance slit to 1 degree by 0.1 degree for two of the detectors (G channel - 113 to 192 nm and N channel - 282 to 432 nm) and by one of the spectrometer exit slits to 0.4 degree by 0.1 degree for the third detector (F channel - 162 to 323 nm). Spectral scanning is accomplished using a fully programmable diffraction grating (2400 lines/mm) drive. Three separate EMR Photoelectric Corp. 510 photomultiplier detectors, located in the exit focal plane of the spectrometer, are used to cover the entire ultraviolet-near-visible spectrum from 113 to 432 nm. Spectral scanning, instrument command and control, data formatting, and spacecraft interface are all normally controlled by an RCA 1802 CMOS microprocessor within the instrument. A hardware-controlled logic circuit, called Cold Start Mode, controls scanning at power on in the event normal commanding capability is inadvertently lost.
